service.name: Amazon Elastic Load Balancing
service.documentation: Elastic Load Balancing automatically distributes incoming application traffic across multiple Amazon EC2 instances. It enables you to achieve greater levels of fault tolerance in your applications, seamlessly providing the required amount of load balancing capacity needed to distribute application traffic.

cabal.name: Amazon Elastic Load Balancing
cabal.description: Elastic Load Balancing automatically distributes incoming application traffic across multiple Amazon EC2 instances. It enables you to achieve greater levels of fault tolerance in your applications, seamlessly providing the required amount of load balancing capacity needed to distribute application traffic.

optional.name: _ssgOwnerAlias
optional.documentation: Owner of the source security group. Use this value for the --source-group-user parameter of the ec2-authorize command in the Amazon EC2 command line tool.

optional.name: _ssgGroupName
optional.documentation: Name of the source security group. Use this value for the --source-group parameter of the ec2-authorize command in the Amazon EC2 command line tool.

fields.name: _ssgGroupName
fields.documentation: Name of the source security group. Use this value for the --source-group parameter of the ec2-authorize command in the Amazon EC2 command line tool.

optional.name: _patdAttributeName
optional.documentation: The name of the attribute associated with the policy type.

optional.name: _patdAttributeType
optional.documentation: The type of attribute. For example, Boolean, Integer, etc.

optional.name: _patdDescription
optional.documentation: A human-readable description of the attribute.

optional.name: _patdDefaultValue
optional.documentation: The default value of the attribute, if applicable.

optional.name: _patdCardinality
optional.documentation:
The cardinality of the attribute. Valid Values:

  • ONE(1) : Single value required
  • ZERO_OR_ONE(0..1) : Up to one value can be supplied
  • ZERO_OR_MORE(0..*) : Optional. Multiple values are allowed
  • ONE_OR_MORE(1..*0) : Required. Multiple values are allowed

fields.name: _patdDescription

required.name: _hcTarget
required.documentation:
Specifies the instance being checked. The protocol is either TCP, HTTP, HTTPS, or SSL. The range of valid ports is one (1) through 65535.

TCP is the default, specified as a TCP: port pair, for example "TCP:5000". In this case a healthcheck simply attempts to open a TCP connection to the instance on the specified port. Failure to connect within the configured timeout is considered unhealthy.

SSL is also specified as SSL: port pair, for example, SSL:5000.

For HTTP or HTTPS protocol, the situation is different. You have to include a ping path in the string. HTTP is specified as a HTTP:port;/;PathToPing; grouping, for example "HTTP:80/weather/us/wa/seattle". In this case, a HTTP GET request is issued to the instance on the given port and path. Any answer other than "200 OK" within the timeout period is considered unhealthy.

The total length of the HTTP ping target needs to be 1024 16-bit Unicode characters or less.

required.name: _hcInterval
required.documentation: Specifies the approximate interval, in seconds, between health checks of an individual instance.

required.name: _hcTimeout
required.documentation:
Specifies the amount of time, in seconds, during which no response means a failed health probe.

This value must be less than the Interval value.

required.name: _hcUnhealthyThreshold
required.documentation: Specifies the number of consecutive health probe failures required before moving the instance to the Unhealthy state.

required.name: _hcHealthyThreshold
required.documentation: Specifies the number of consecutive health probe successes required before moving the instance to the Healthy state.

fields.name: _hcHealthyThreshold
fields.documentation: Specifies the number of consecutive health probe successes required before moving the instance to the Healthy state.

fields.name: _hcInterval
fields.documentation: Specifies the approximate interval, in seconds, between health checks of an individual instance.

fields.name: _hcTarget
fields.documentation:
Specifies the instance being checked. The protocol is either TCP, HTTP, HTTPS, or SSL. The range of valid ports is one (1) through 65535.

TCP is the default, specified as a TCP: port pair, for example "TCP:5000". In this case a healthcheck simply attempts to open a TCP connection to the instance on the specified port. Failure to connect within the configured timeout is considered unhealthy.

SSL is also specified as SSL: port pair, for example, SSL:5000.

For HTTP or HTTPS protocol, the situation is different. You have to include a ping path in the string. HTTP is specified as a HTTP:port;/;PathToPing; grouping, for example "HTTP:80/weather/us/wa/seattle". In this case, a HTTP GET request is issued to the instance on the given port and path. Any answer other than "200 OK" within the timeout period is considered unhealthy.

The total length of the HTTP ping target needs to be 1024 16-bit Unicode characters or less.

fields.name: _hcTimeout
fields.documentation:
Specifies the amount of time, in seconds, during which no response means a failed health probe.

This value must be less than the Interval value.

fields.name: _hcUnhealthyThreshold
fields.documentation: Specifies the number of consecutive health probe failures required before moving the instance to the Unhealthy state.

field.name: _czlbEnabled
field.documentation: Specifies whether cross-zone load balancing is enabled for the load balancer.

required.name: _czlbEnabled
required.documentation: Specifies whether cross-zone load balancing is enabled for the load balancer.

fields.name: _czlbEnabled
fields.documentation: Specifies whether cross-zone load balancing is enabled for the load balancer.

optional.name: _lbaCrossZoneLoadBalancing
optional.documentation:
The name of the load balancer attribute. If enabled, the load balancer routes the request traffic evenly across all back-end instances regardless of the Availability Zones.

For more information, see Enable Cross-Zone Load Balancing.

optional.name: _lbaAccessLog
optional.documentation:
The name of the load balancer attribute. If enabled, the load balancer captures detailed information of all the requests and delivers the information to the Amazon S3 bucket that you specify.

For more information, see Enable Access Logs.

optional.name: _lbaConnectionDraining
optional.documentation:
The name of the load balancer attribute. If enabled, the load balancer allows existing requests to complete before the load balancer shifts traffic away from a deregistered or unhealthy back-end instance.

For more information, see Enable Connection Draining.

optional.name: _lbaConnectionSettings
optional.documentation:
The name of the load balancer attribute.

By default, Elastic Load Balancing maintains a 60-second idle connection timeout for both front-end and back-end connections of your load balancer. If the ConnectionSettings attribute is set, Elastic Load Balancing will allow the connections to remain idle (no data is sent over the connection) for the specified duration.

For more information, see Configure Idle Connection Timeout.

fields.name: _lbaAccessLog
fields.documentation:
The name of the load balancer attribute. If enabled, the load balancer captures detailed information of all the requests and delivers the information to the Amazon S3 bucket that you specify.

For more information, see Enable Access Logs.

fields.name: _lbaConnectionDraining
fields.documentation:
The name of the load balancer attribute. If enabled, the load balancer allows existing requests to complete before the load balancer shifts traffic away from a deregistered or unhealthy back-end instance.

For more information, see Enable Connection Draining.

fields.name: _lbaConnectionSettings
fields.documentation:
The name of the load balancer attribute.

By default, Elastic Load Balancing maintains a 60-second idle connection timeout for both front-end and back-end connections of your load balancer. If the ConnectionSettings attribute is set, Elastic Load Balancing will allow the connections to remain idle (no data is sent over the connection) for the specified duration.

For more information, see Configure Idle Connection Timeout.

fields.name: _lbaCrossZoneLoadBalancing
fields.documentation:
The name of the load balancer attribute. If enabled, the load balancer routes the request traffic evenly across all back-end instances regardless of the Availability Zones.

For more information, see Enable Cross-Zone Load Balancing.

required.name: _alEnabled
required.documentation: Specifies whether access log is enabled for the load balancer.

optional.name: _alS3BucketName
optional.documentation: The name of the Amazon S3 bucket where the access logs are stored.

optional.name: _alEmitInterval
optional.documentation:
The interval for publishing the access logs. You can specify an interval of either 5 minutes or 60 minutes.

Default: 60 minutes

optional.name: _alS3BucketPrefix
optional.documentation: The logical hierarchy you created for your Amazon S3 bucket, for example my-bucket-prefix/prod. If the prefix is not provided, the log is placed at the root level of the bucket.

fields.name: _alEmitInterval
fields.documentation:
The interval for publishing the access logs. You can specify an interval of either 5 minutes or 60 minutes.

Default: 60 minutes

optional.name: _ldPolicyNames
optional.documentation: A list of policies enabled for this listener. An empty list indicates that no policies are enabled.

optional.documentation: The time period in seconds after which the cookie should be considered stale. Not specifying this parameter indicates that the stickiness session will last for the duration of the browser session.

optional.documentation: Specifies the name associated with the load balancer.

optional.documentation: Specifies the external DNS name associated with the load balancer.

optional.name: _lbdCanonicalHostedZoneName
optional.documentation: Provides the name of the Amazon Route 53 hosted zone that is associated with the load balancer. For information on how to associate your load balancer with a hosted zone, go to Using Domain Names With Elastic Load Balancing in the Elastic Load Balancing Developer Guide.

optional.name: _lbdCanonicalHostedZoneNameID
optional.documentation: Provides the ID of the Amazon Route 53 hosted zone name that is associated with the load balancer. For information on how to associate or disassociate your load balancer with a hosted zone, go to Using Domain Names With Elastic Load Balancing in the Elastic Load Balancing Developer Guide.

optional.name: _lbdListenerDescriptions
optional.documentation: LoadBalancerPort, InstancePort, Protocol, InstanceProtocol, and PolicyNames are returned in a list of tuples in the ListenerDescriptions element.

optional.name: _lbdPolicies
optional.documentation: Provides a list of policies defined for the load balancer.

optional.name: _lbdBackendServerDescriptions
optional.documentation: Contains a list of back-end server descriptions.

optional.name: _lbdAvailabilityZones
optional.documentation: Specifies a list of Availability Zones.

optional.name: _lbdSubnets
optional.documentation: Provides a list of VPC subnet IDs for the load balancer.

optional.name: _lbdVPCId
optional.documentation: Provides the ID of the VPC attached to the load balancer.

optional.name: _lbdInstances
optional.documentation: Provides a list of EC2 instance IDs for the load balancer.

optional.name: _lbdHealthCheck
optional.documentation: Specifies information regarding the various health probes conducted on the load balancer.

optional.name: _lbdSourceSecurityGroup
optional.documentation: The security group that you can use as part of your inbound rules for your load balancer's back-end Amazon EC2 application instances. To only allow traffic from load balancers, add a security group rule to your back end instance that specifies this source security group as the inbound source.

optional.name: _lbdSecurityGroups
optional.documentation: The security groups the load balancer is a member of (VPC only).

optional.name: _lbdCreatedTime
optional.documentation: Provides the date and time the load balancer was created.

optional.name: _lbdScheme
optional.documentation:
Specifies the type of load balancer.

If the Scheme is internet-facing, the load balancer has a publicly resolvable DNS name that resolves to public IP addresses.

If the Scheme is internal, the load balancer has a publicly resolvable DNS name that resolves to private IP addresses.

This option is only available for load balancers attached to an Amazon VPC.

required.name: _lProtocol
required.documentation: Specifies the load balancer transport protocol to use for routing - HTTP, HTTPS, TCP or SSL. This property cannot be modified for the life of the load balancer.

required.name: _lLoadBalancerPort
required.documentation: Specifies the external load balancer port number. This property cannot be modified for the life of the load balancer.

required.name: _lInstancePort
required.documentation: Specifies the TCP port on which the instance server is listening. This property cannot be modified for the life of the load balancer.

optional.name: _lInstanceProtocol
optional.documentation:
Specifies the protocol to use for routing traffic to back-end instances - HTTP, HTTPS, TCP, or SSL. This property cannot be modified for the life of the load balancer.

If the front-end protocol is HTTP or HTTPS, InstanceProtocol has to be at the same protocol layer, i.e., HTTP or HTTPS. Likewise, if the front-end protocol is TCP or SSL, InstanceProtocol has to be TCP or SSL. If there is another listener with the same InstancePort whose InstanceProtocol is secure, i.e., HTTPS or SSL, the listener's InstanceProtocol has to be secure, i.e., HTTPS or SSL. If there is another listener with the same InstancePort whose InstanceProtocol is HTTP or TCP, the listener's InstanceProtocol must be either HTTP or TCP.

optional.name: _lSSLCertificateId
optional.documentation: The ARN string of the server certificate. To get the ARN of the server certificate, call the AWS Identity and Access Management UploadServerCertificate API.

fields.name: _lInstancePort
fields.documentation: Specifies the TCP port on which the instance server is listening. This property cannot be modified for the life of the load balancer.

fields.name: _lInstanceProtocol
fields.documentation:
Specifies the protocol to use for routing traffic to back-end instances - HTTP, HTTPS, TCP, or SSL. This property cannot be modified for the life of the load balancer.

If the front-end protocol is HTTP or HTTPS, InstanceProtocol has to be at the same protocol layer, i.e., HTTP or HTTPS. Likewise, if the front-end protocol is TCP or SSL, InstanceProtocol has to be TCP or SSL. If there is another listener with the same InstancePort whose InstanceProtocol is secure, i.e., HTTPS or SSL, the listener's InstanceProtocol has to be secure, i.e., HTTPS or SSL. If there is another listener with the same InstancePort whose InstanceProtocol is HTTP or TCP, the listener's InstanceProtocol must be either HTTP or TCP.

fields.name: _lLoadBalancerPort

fields.name: _lProtocol

fields.name: _lSSLCertificateId
fields.documentation: The ARN string of the server certificate. To get the ARN of the server certificate, call the AWS Identity and Access Management UploadServerCertificate API.

optional.name: _cdTimeout
optional.documentation: Specifies the maximum time (in seconds) to keep the existing connections open before deregistering the instances.

Specifies the current state of the instance.

Valid value: InService|OutOfService|Unknown

optional.name: _isReasonCode

Provides information about the cause of OutOfService instances. Specifically, it indicates whether the cause is Elastic Load Balancing or the instance behind the load balancer.

Valid value: ELB|Instance|N/A

operations.name: AddTags
operations.documentation:
Adds one or more tags for the specified load balancer. Each load balancer can have a maximum of 10 tags. Each tag consists of a key and an optional value.

Tag keys must be unique for each load balancer. If a tag with the same key is already associated with the load balancer, this action will update the value of the key.

For more information, see Tagging in the Elastic Load Balancing Developer Guide.

required.name: _atTags
required.documentation: A list of tags for each load balancer.

optional.name: _atLoadBalancerNames
optional.documentation: The name of the load balancer to tag. You can specify a maximum of one load balancer name.

fields.name: _atLoadBalancerNames
fields.documentation: The name of the load balancer to tag. You can specify a maximum of one load balancer name.

fields.name: _atTags
fields.documentation: A list of tags for each load balancer.

field.name: _asgtlbrSecurityGroups
field.documentation: A list of security group IDs associated with your load balancer.

optional.name: _asgtlbrSecurityGroups
optional.documentation: A list of security group IDs associated with your load balancer.

fields.name: _asgtlbrSecurityGroups
fields.documentation: A list of security group IDs associated with your load balancer.

operations.name: ApplySecurityGroupsToLoadBalancer
operations.documentation:
Associates one or more security groups with your load balancer in Amazon Virtual Private Cloud (Amazon VPC). The provided security group IDs will override any currently applied security groups.

For more information, see Manage Security Groups in Amazon VPC in the Elastic Load Balancing Developer Guide.

required.name: _asgtlbLoadBalancerName
required.documentation: The name associated with the load balancer. The name must be unique within the set of load balancers associated with your AWS account.

optional.name: _asgtlbSecurityGroups
optional.documentation: A list of security group IDs to associate with your load balancer in VPC. The security group IDs must be provided as the ID and not the security group name (For example, sg-1234).

fields.name: _asgtlbLoadBalancerName
fields.documentation: The name associated with the load balancer. The name must be unique within the set of load balancers associated with your AWS account.

fields.name: _asgtlbSecurityGroups
fields.documentation: A list of security group IDs to associate with your load balancer in VPC. The security group IDs must be provided as the ID and not the security group name (For example, sg-1234).

field.name: _albtsrSubnets
field.documentation: A list of subnet IDs attached to the load balancer.

optional.name: _albtsrSubnets
optional.documentation: A list of subnet IDs attached to the load balancer.

fields.name: _albtsrSubnets
fields.documentation: A list of subnet IDs attached to the load balancer.

operations.name: AttachLoadBalancerToSubnets
operations.documentation:
Adds one or more subnets to the set of configured subnets in the Amazon Virtual Private Cloud (Amazon VPC) for the load balancer.

The load balancers evenly distribute requests across all of the registered subnets. For more information, see Deploy Elastic Load Balancing in Amazon VPC in the Elastic Load Balancing Developer Guide.

required.name: _albtsLoadBalancerName
required.documentation: The name associated with the load balancer. The name must be unique within the set of load balancers associated with your AWS account.

optional.name: _albtsSubnets
optional.documentation: A list of subnet IDs to add for the load balancer. You can add only one subnet per Availability Zone.

fields.name: _albtsLoadBalancerName
fields.documentation: The name associated with the load balancer. The name must be unique within the set of load balancers associated with your AWS account.

fields.name: _albtsSubnets
fields.documentation: A list of subnet IDs to add for the load balancer. You can add only one subnet per Availability Zone.

field.name: _chcrHealthCheck
field.documentation: The updated healthcheck for the instances.

optional.name: _chcrHealthCheck
optional.documentation: The updated healthcheck for the instances.

fields.name: _chcrHealthCheck
fields.documentation: The updated healthcheck for the instances.

operations.name: ConfigureHealthCheck
operations.documentation:
Specifies the health check settings to use for evaluating the health state of your back-end instances.

For more information, see Health Check in the Elastic Load Balancing Developer Guide.

required.name: _chcLoadBalancerName
required.documentation: The mnemonic name associated with the load balancer. The name must be unique within the set of load balancers associated with your AWS account.

required.name: _chcHealthCheck
required.documentation: A structure containing the configuration information for the new healthcheck.

fields.name: _chcHealthCheck
fields.documentation: A structure containing the configuration information for the new healthcheck.

fields.name: _chcLoadBalancerName
fields.documentation: The mnemonic name associated with the load balancer. The name must be unique within the set of load balancers associated with your AWS account.

operations.name: CreateAppCookieStickinessPolicy
operations.documentation:
Generates a stickiness policy with sticky session lifetimes that follow that of an application-generated cookie. This policy can be associated only with HTTP/HTTPS listeners.

This policy is similar to the policy created by CreateLBCookieStickinessPolicy, except that the lifetime of the special Elastic Load Balancing cookie follows the lifetime of the application-generated cookie specified in the policy configuration. The load balancer only inserts a new stickiness cookie when the application response includes a new application cookie.

If the application cookie is explicitly removed or expires, the session stops being sticky until a new application cookie is issued.

An application client must receive and send two cookies: the application-generated cookie and the special Elastic Load Balancing cookie named AWSELB. This is the default behavior for many common web browsers.

For more information, see Enabling Application-Controlled Session Stickiness in the Elastic Load Balancing Developer Guide.

required.name: _cacspLoadBalancerName
required.documentation: The name of the load balancer.

required.name: _cacspPolicyName
required.documentation: The name of the policy being created. The name must be unique within the set of policies for this load balancer.

required.name: _cacspCookieName
required.documentation: Name of the application cookie used for stickiness.

fields.name: _cacspCookieName
fields.documentation: Name of the application cookie used for stickiness.

fields.name: _cacspLoadBalancerName
fields.documentation: The name of the load balancer.

fields.name: _cacspPolicyName
fields.documentation: The name of the policy being created. The name must be unique within the set of policies for this load balancer.

operations.name: CreateLBCookieStickinessPolicy
operations.documentation:
Generates a stickiness policy with sticky session lifetimes controlled by the lifetime of the browser (user-agent) or a specified expiration period. This policy can be associated only with HTTP/HTTPS listeners.

When a load balancer implements this policy, the load balancer uses a special cookie to track the backend server instance for each request. When the load balancer receives a request, it first checks to see if this cookie is present in the request. If so, the load balancer sends the request to the application server specified in the cookie. If not, the load balancer sends the request to a server that is chosen based on the existing load balancing algorithm.

A cookie is inserted into the response for binding subsequent requests from the same user to that server. The validity of the cookie is based on the cookie expiration time, which is specified in the policy configuration.

For more information, see Enabling Duration-Based Session Stickiness in the Elastic Load Balancing Developer Guide.

required.name: _clbcspLoadBalancerName
required.documentation: The name associated with the load balancer.

required.name: _clbcspPolicyName
required.documentation: The name of the policy being created. The name must be unique within the set of policies for this load balancer.

optional.name: _clbcspCookieExpirationPeriod
optional.documentation: The time period in seconds after which the cookie should be considered stale. Not specifying this parameter indicates that the sticky session will last for the duration of the browser session.

fields.name: _clbcspCookieExpirationPeriod
fields.documentation: The time period in seconds after which the cookie should be considered stale. Not specifying this parameter indicates that the sticky session will last for the duration of the browser session.

fields.name: _clbcspLoadBalancerName
fields.documentation: The name associated with the load balancer.

fields.name: _clbcspPolicyName
fields.documentation: The name of the policy being created. The name must be unique within the set of policies for this load balancer.

field.name: _clbrDNSName
field.documentation: The DNS name for the load balancer.

optional.name: _clbrDNSName
optional.documentation: The DNS name for the load balancer.

fields.name: _clbrDNSName
fields.documentation: The DNS name for the load balancer.

operations.name: CreateLoadBalancer
operations.documentation:
Creates a new load balancer.

After the call has completed successfully, a new load balancer is created with a unique Domain Name Service (DNS) name. The DNS name includes the name of the AWS region in which the load balance was created. For example, if your load balancer was created in the United States, the DNS name might end with either of the following:

  • us-east-1.elb.amazonaws.com (for the Northern Virginia region)
  • us-west-1.elb.amazonaws.com (for the Northern California region)

For information about the AWS regions supported by Elastic Load Balancing, see Regions and Endpoints.

You can create up to 20 load balancers per region per account.

Elastic Load Balancing supports load balancing your Amazon EC2 instances launched within any one of the following platforms:

  • EC2-Classic

    For information on creating and managing your load balancers in EC2-Classic, see Deploy Elastic Load Balancing in Amazon EC2-Classic.

  • EC2-VPC

    For information on creating and managing your load balancers in EC2-VPC, see Deploy Elastic Load Balancing in Amazon VPC.

required.name: _clbLoadBalancerName
required.documentation: The name associated with the load balancer. The name must be unique within your set of load balancers, must have a maximum of 32 characters, and must only contain alphanumeric characters or hyphens.

required.name: _clbTags
required.documentation:
A list of tags to assign to the load balancer.

For more information about setting tags for your load balancer, see Tagging.

optional.name: _clbListeners
optional.documentation: A list of the following tuples: Protocol, LoadBalancerPort, InstanceProtocol, InstancePort, and SSLCertificateId.

optional.name: _clbAvailabilityZones
optional.documentation:
A list of Availability Zones.

At least one Availability Zone must be specified. Specified Availability Zones must be in the same EC2 Region as the load balancer. Traffic will be equally distributed across all zones.

You can later add more Availability Zones after the creation of the load balancer by calling EnableAvailabilityZonesForLoadBalancer action.

optional.name: _clbSubnets
optional.documentation: A list of subnet IDs in your VPC to attach to your load balancer. Specify one subnet per Availability Zone.

optional.name: _clbSecurityGroups
optional.documentation: The security groups to assign to your load balancer within your VPC.

optional.name: _clbScheme
optional.documentation:
The type of a load balancer.

By default, Elastic Load Balancing creates an Internet-facing load balancer with a publicly resolvable DNS name, which resolves to public IP addresses. For more information about Internet-facing and Internal load balancers, see Internet-facing and Internal Load Balancers.

Specify the value internal for this option to create an internal load balancer with a DNS name that resolves to private IP addresses.

This option is only available for load balancers created within EC2-VPC.

fields.name: _clbAvailabilityZones
fields.documentation:
A list of Availability Zones.

At least one Availability Zone must be specified. Specified Availability Zones must be in the same EC2 Region as the load balancer. Traffic will be equally distributed across all zones.

You can later add more Availability Zones after the creation of the load balancer by calling EnableAvailabilityZonesForLoadBalancer action.

fields.name: _clbListeners
fields.documentation: A list of the following tuples: Protocol, LoadBalancerPort, InstanceProtocol, InstancePort, and SSLCertificateId.

fields.name: _clbLoadBalancerName
fields.documentation: The name associated with the load balancer. The name must be unique within your set of load balancers, must have a maximum of 32 characters, and must only contain alphanumeric characters or hyphens.

fields.name: _clbScheme
fields.documentation:
The type of a load balancer.

By default, Elastic Load Balancing creates an Internet-facing load balancer with a publicly resolvable DNS name, which resolves to public IP addresses. For more information about Internet-facing and Internal load balancers, see Internet-facing and Internal Load Balancers.

Specify the value internal for this option to create an internal load balancer with a DNS name that resolves to private IP addresses.

This option is only available for load balancers created within EC2-VPC.

fields.name: _clbSecurityGroups
fields.documentation: The security groups to assign to your load balancer within your VPC.

fields.name: _clbSubnets
fields.documentation: A list of subnet IDs in your VPC to attach to your load balancer. Specify one subnet per Availability Zone.

fields.name: _clbTags
fields.documentation:
A list of tags to assign to the load balancer.

For more information about setting tags for your load balancer, see Tagging.

operations.name: CreateLoadBalancerListeners
operations.documentation:
Creates one or more listeners on a load balancer for the specified port. If a listener with the given port does not already exist, it will be created; otherwise, the properties of the new listener must match the properties of the existing listener.

For more information, see Add a Listener to Your Load Balancer in the Elastic Load Balancing Developer Guide.

required.name: _clblLoadBalancerName
required.documentation: The name of the load balancer.

optional.name: _clblListeners
optional.documentation: A list of LoadBalancerPort, InstancePort, Protocol, InstanceProtocol, and SSLCertificateId items.

fields.name: _clblListeners
fields.documentation: A list of LoadBalancerPort, InstancePort, Protocol, InstanceProtocol, and SSLCertificateId items.

fields.name: _clblLoadBalancerName
fields.documentation: The name of the load balancer.

operations.name: CreateLoadBalancerPolicy
operations.documentation: Creates a new policy that contains the necessary attributes depending on the policy type. Policies are settings that are saved for your load balancer and that can be applied to the front-end listener, or the back-end application server, depending on your policy type.

required.name: _clbpLoadBalancerName
required.documentation: The name associated with the LoadBalancer for which the policy is being created.

required.name: _clbpPolicyName
required.documentation: The name of the load balancer policy being created. The name must be unique within the set of policies for this load balancer.

required.name: _clbpPolicyTypeName
required.documentation: The name of the base policy type being used to create this policy. To get the list of policy types, use the DescribeLoadBalancerPolicyTypes action.

optional.name: _clbpPolicyAttributes
optional.documentation: A list of attributes associated with the policy being created.

fields.name: _clbpLoadBalancerName
fields.documentation: The name associated with the LoadBalancer for which the policy is being created.

fields.name: _clbpPolicyAttributes
fields.documentation: A list of attributes associated with the policy being created.

fields.name: _clbpPolicyName
fields.documentation: The name of the load balancer policy being created. The name must be unique within the set of policies for this load balancer.

fields.name: _clbpPolicyTypeName
fields.documentation: The name of the base policy type being used to create this policy. To get the list of policy types, use the DescribeLoadBalancerPolicyTypes action.

operations.name: DeleteLoadBalancer
operations.documentation:
Deletes the specified load balancer.

If attempting to recreate the load balancer, you must reconfigure all the settings. The DNS name associated with a deleted load balancer will no longer be usable. Once deleted, the name and associated DNS record of the load balancer no longer exist and traffic sent to any of its IP addresses will no longer be delivered to back-end instances.

To successfully call this API, you must provide the same account credentials as were used to create the load balancer.

By design, if the load balancer does not exist or has already been deleted, a call to DeleteLoadBalancer action still succeeds.

field.name: _dlbLoadBalancerName
field.documentation: The name associated with the load balancer.

required.name: _dlbLoadBalancerName
required.documentation: The name associated with the load balancer.

fields.name: _dlbLoadBalancerName
fields.documentation: The name associated with the load balancer.

operations.name: DeleteLoadBalancerListeners
operations.documentation: Deletes listeners from the load balancer for the specified port.

required.name: _dlblLoadBalancerName
required.documentation: The mnemonic name associated with the load balancer.

optional.name: _dlblLoadBalancerPorts
optional.documentation: The client port number(s) of the load balancer listener(s) to be removed.

fields.documentation: The mnemonic name associated with the load balancer.

fields.name: _dlblLoadBalancerPorts
fields.documentation: The client port number(s) of the load balancer listener(s) to be removed.

operations.name: DeleteLoadBalancerPolicy
operations.documentation: Deletes a policy from the load balancer. The specified policy must not be enabled for any listeners.

optional.documentation: An updated list of remaining instances registered with the load balancer.

fields.name: _diflbrInstances

operations.name: DeregisterInstancesFromLoadBalancer
operations.documentation:
Deregisters instances from the load balancer. Once the instance is deregistered, it will stop receiving traffic from the load balancer.

In order to successfully call this API, the same account credentials as those used to create the load balancer must be provided.

For more information, see De-register and Register Amazon EC2 Instances in the Elastic Load Balancing Developer Guide.

You can use DescribeLoadBalancers to verify if the instance is deregistered from the load balancer.

required.name: _diflbLoadBalancerName
required.documentation: The name associated with the load balancer.

optional.name: _diflbInstances
optional.documentation: A list of EC2 instance IDs consisting of all instances to be deregistered.

fields.name: _diflbInstances
fields.documentation: A list of EC2 instance IDs consisting of all instances to be deregistered.

fields.name: _diflbLoadBalancerName

operations.name: DescribeInstanceHealth
operations.documentation:
Returns the current state of the specified instances registered with the specified load balancer. If no instances are specified, the state of all the instances registered with the load balancer is returned.

You must provide the same account credentials as those that were used to create the load balancer.

required.name: _dihLoadBalancerName
required.documentation: The name of the load balancer.

optional.name: _dihInstances
optional.documentation: A list of instance IDs whose states are being queried.

fields.name: _dihInstances

fields.name: _dihLoadBalancerName

operations.documentation: Returns detailed information about all of the attributes associated with the specified load balancer.

field.name: _dlbaLoadBalancerName

required.name: _dlbaLoadBalancerName
required.documentation: The name of the load balancer.

fields.name: _dlbaLoadBalancerName

optional.name: _dlbprPolicyDescriptions
optional.documentation: A list of policy description structures.

operations.name: DescribeLoadBalancerPolicies
operations.documentation: Returns detailed descriptions of the policies. If you specify a load balancer name, the action returns the descriptions of all the policies created for the load balancer. If you specify a policy name associated with your load balancer, the action returns the description of that policy. If you don't specify a load balancer name, the action returns descriptions of the specified sample policies, or descriptions of all the sample policies. The names of the sample policies have the ELBSample- prefix.

optional.name: _dlbpLoadBalancerName
optional.documentation: The mnemonic name associated with the load balancer. If no name is specified, the operation returns the attributes of either all the sample policies pre-defined by Elastic Load Balancing or the specified sample polices.

optional.name: _dlbpPolicyNames
optional.documentation: The names of load balancer policies you've created or Elastic Load Balancing sample policy names.

fields.name: _dlbpLoadBalancerName
fields.documentation: The mnemonic name associated with the load balancer. If no name is specified, the operation returns the attributes of either all the sample policies pre-defined by Elastic Load Balancing or the specified sample polices.

fields.name: _dlbpPolicyNames
fields.documentation: The names of load balancer policies you've created or Elastic Load Balancing sample policy names.

field.name: _dlbptrPolicyTypeDescriptions
field.documentation: List of policy type description structures of the specified policy type. If no policy type names are specified, returns the description of all the policy types defined by Elastic Load Balancing service.

optional.name: _dlbptrPolicyTypeDescriptions
optional.documentation: List of policy type description structures of the specified policy type. If no policy type names are specified, returns the description of all the policy types defined by Elastic Load Balancing service.

fields.name: _dlbptrPolicyTypeDescriptions
fields.documentation: List of policy type description structures of the specified policy type. If no policy type names are specified, returns the description of all the policy types defined by Elastic Load Balancing service.

operations.name: DescribeLoadBalancerPolicyTypes
operations.documentation: Returns meta-information on the specified load balancer policies defined by the Elastic Load Balancing service. The policy types that are returned from this action can be used in a CreateLoadBalancerPolicy action to instantiate specific policy configurations that will be applied to a load balancer.

field.name: _dlbptPolicyTypeNames
field.documentation: Specifies the name of the policy types. If no names are specified, returns the description of all the policy types defined by Elastic Load Balancing service.

optional.name: _dlbptPolicyTypeNames
optional.documentation: Specifies the name of the policy types. If no names are specified, returns the description of all the policy types defined by Elastic Load Balancing service.

fields.name: _dlbptPolicyTypeNames
fields.documentation: Specifies the name of the policy types. If no names are specified, returns the description of all the policy types defined by Elastic Load Balancing service.

optional.name: _dlbrLoadBalancerDescriptions
optional.documentation: A list of load balancer description structures.

optional.name: _dlbrNextMarker
optional.documentation: Specifies the value of next marker if the request returned more than one page of results.

fields.name: _dlbrLoadBalancerDescriptions
fields.documentation: A list of load balancer description structures.

fields.name: _dlbrNextMarker
fields.documentation: Specifies the value of next marker if the request returned more than one page of results.

operations.name: DescribeLoadBalancers
operations.documentation:
Returns detailed configuration information for all the load balancers created for the account. If you specify load balancer names, the action returns configuration information of the specified load balancers.

In order to retrieve this information, you must provide the same account credentials that was used to create the load balancer.

optional.name: _dlbLoadBalancerNames
optional.documentation: A list of load balancer names associated with the account.

optional.name: _dlbMarker
optional.documentation: An optional parameter used for pagination of results from this call. If specified, the response includes only records beyond the marker.

optional.name: _dlbPageSize
optional.documentation: The number of results returned in each page. The default is 400. You cannot specify a page size greater than 400 or less than 1.

fields.name: _dlbLoadBalancerNames
fields.documentation: A list of load balancer names associated with the account.

fields.name: _dlbMarker
fields.documentation: An optional parameter used for pagination of results from this call. If specified, the response includes only records beyond the marker.

fields.name: _dlbPageSize
fields.documentation: The number of results returned in each page. The default is 400. You cannot specify a page size greater than 400 or less than 1.

field.name: _dtrTagDescriptions
field.documentation: A list of tag description structures.

optional.name: _dtrTagDescriptions
optional.documentation: A list of tag description structures.

fields.name: _dtrTagDescriptions
fields.documentation: A list of tag description structures.

operations.name: DescribeTags
operations.documentation: Describes the tags associated with one or more load balancers.

field.name: _dtLoadBalancerNames
field.documentation: The names of the load balancers.

required.name: _dtLoadBalancerNames
required.documentation: The names of the load balancers.

fields.name: _dtLoadBalancerNames
fields.documentation: The names of the load balancers.

field.name: _dlbfsrSubnets
field.documentation: A list of subnet IDs the load balancer is now attached to.

optional.name: _dlbfsrSubnets
optional.documentation: A list of subnet IDs the load balancer is now attached to.

fields.name: _dlbfsrSubnets
fields.documentation: A list of subnet IDs the load balancer is now attached to.

operations.name: DetachLoadBalancerFromSubnets
operations.documentation:
Removes subnets from the set of configured subnets in the Amazon Virtual Private Cloud (Amazon VPC) for the load balancer.

After a subnet is removed all of the EC2 instances registered with the load balancer that are in the removed subnet will go into the OutOfService state. When a subnet is removed, the load balancer will balance the traffic among the remaining routable subnets for the load balancer.

required.name: _dlbfsLoadBalancerName
required.documentation: The name associated with the load balancer to be detached.

optional.name: _dlbfsSubnets
optional.documentation: A list of subnet IDs to remove from the set of configured subnets for the load balancer.

fields.name: _dlbfsLoadBalancerName
fields.documentation: The name associated with the load balancer to be detached.

fields.name: _dlbfsSubnets
fields.documentation: A list of subnet IDs to remove from the set of configured subnets for the load balancer.

field.name: _dazflbrAvailabilityZones
field.documentation: A list of updated Availability Zones for the load balancer.

optional.name: _dazflbrAvailabilityZones
optional.documentation: A list of updated Availability Zones for the load balancer.

fields.name: _dazflbrAvailabilityZones
fields.documentation: A list of updated Availability Zones for the load balancer.

operations.name: DisableAvailabilityZonesForLoadBalancer
operations.documentation:
Removes the specified EC2 Availability Zones from the set of configured Availability Zones for the load balancer.

There must be at least one Availability Zone registered with a load balancer at all times. Once an Availability Zone is removed, all the instances registered with the load balancer that are in the removed Availability Zone go into the OutOfService state. Upon Availability Zone removal, the load balancer attempts to equally balance the traffic among its remaining usable Availability Zones. Trying to remove an Availability Zone that was not associated with the load balancer does nothing.

For more information, see Disable an Availability Zone from a Load-Balanced Application in the Elastic Load Balancing Developer Guide.

required.name: _dazflbLoadBalancerName
required.documentation: The name associated with the load balancer.

optional.name: _dazflbAvailabilityZones
optional.documentation:
A list of Availability Zones to be removed from the load balancer.

There must be at least one Availability Zone registered with a load balancer at all times. Specified Availability Zones must be in the same region.

fields.name: _dazflbAvailabilityZones
fields.documentation:
A list of Availability Zones to be removed from the load balancer.

There must be at least one Availability Zone registered with a load balancer at all times. Specified Availability Zones must be in the same region.

fields.name: _dazflbLoadBalancerName
fields.documentation: The name associated with the load balancer.

field.name: _eazflbrAvailabilityZones
field.documentation: An updated list of Availability Zones for the load balancer.

optional.name: _eazflbrAvailabilityZones
optional.documentation: An updated list of Availability Zones for the load balancer.

fields.name: _eazflbrAvailabilityZones
fields.documentation: An updated list of Availability Zones for the load balancer.

operations.name: EnableAvailabilityZonesForLoadBalancer
operations.documentation:
Adds one or more EC2 Availability Zones to the load balancer.

The load balancer evenly distributes requests across all its registered Availability Zones that contain instances.

The new EC2 Availability Zones to be added must be in the same EC2 Region as the Availability Zones for which the load balancer was created.

For more information, see Expand a Load Balanced Application to an Additional Availability Zone in the Elastic Load Balancing Developer Guide.

required.name: _eazflbLoadBalancerName
required.documentation: The name associated with the load balancer.

optional.name: _eazflbAvailabilityZones
optional.documentation: A list of new Availability Zones for the load balancer. Each Availability Zone must be in the same region as the load balancer.

fields.name: _eazflbAvailabilityZones
fields.documentation: A list of new Availability Zones for the load balancer. Each Availability Zone must be in the same region as the load balancer.

fields.name: _eazflbLoadBalancerName
fields.documentation: The name associated with the load balancer.

optional.name: _mlbarLoadBalancerName
optional.documentation: The name of the load balancer.

fields.name: _mlbarLoadBalancerName
fields.documentation: The name of the load balancer.

operations.name: ModifyLoadBalancerAttributes
operations.documentation:
Modifies the attributes of a specified load balancer.

You can modify the load balancer attributes, such as AccessLogs, ConnectionDraining, and CrossZoneLoadBalancing by either enabling or disabling them. Or, you can modify the load balancer attribute ConnectionSettings by specifying an idle connection timeout value for your load balancer.

For more information, see the following:

  • Cross-Zone Load Balancing
  • Connection Draining
  • Access Logs
  • Idle Connection Timeout

required.name: _mlbaLoadBalancerName
required.documentation: The name of the load balancer.

required.name: _mlbaLoadBalancerAttributes
required.documentation: Attributes of the load balancer.

fields.name: _mlbaLoadBalancerAttributes
fields.documentation: Attributes of the load balancer.

fields.name: _mlbaLoadBalancerName
fields.documentation: The name of the load balancer.

field.name: _riwlbrInstances
field.documentation: An updated list of instances for the load balancer.

optional.name: _riwlbrInstances
optional.documentation: An updated list of instances for the load balancer.

fields.name: _riwlbrInstances
fields.documentation: An updated list of instances for the load balancer.

operations.name: RegisterInstancesWithLoadBalancer
operations.documentation:
Adds new instances to the load balancer.

Once the instance is registered, it starts receiving traffic and requests from the load balancer. Any instance that is not in any of the Availability Zones registered for the load balancer will be moved to the OutOfService state. It will move to the InService state when the Availability Zone is added to the load balancer.

When an instance registered with a load balancer is stopped and then restarted, the IP addresses associated with the instance changes. Elastic Load Balancing cannot recognize the new IP address, which prevents it from routing traffic to the instances. We recommend that you de-register your Amazon EC2 instances from your load balancer after you stop your instance, and then register the load balancer with your instance after you've restarted. To de-register your instances from load balancer, use DeregisterInstancesFromLoadBalancer action.

For more information, see De-register and Register Amazon EC2 Instances in the Elastic Load Balancing Developer Guide.

In order for this call to be successful, you must provide the same account credentials as those that were used to create the load balancer. Completion of this API does not guarantee that operation has completed. Rather, it means that the request has been registered and the changes will happen shortly.

You can use DescribeLoadBalancers or DescribeInstanceHealth action to check the state of the newly registered instances.

required.name: _riwlbLoadBalancerName
required.documentation: The name associated with the load balancer. The name must be unique within your set of load balancers.

optional.name: _riwlbInstances
optional.documentation: A list of instance IDs that should be registered with the load balancer.

fields.name: _riwlbInstances
fields.documentation: A list of instance IDs that should be registered with the load balancer.

fields.name: _riwlbLoadBalancerName
fields.documentation: The name associated with the load balancer. The name must be unique within your set of load balancers.

operations.name: RemoveTags
operations.documentation: Removes one or more tags from the specified load balancer.

required.name: _rtTags
required.documentation: A list of tag keys to remove.

optional.name: _rtLoadBalancerNames
optional.documentation: The name of the load balancer. You can specify a maximum of one load balancer name.

fields.name: _rtLoadBalancerNames
fields.documentation: The name of the load balancer. You can specify a maximum of one load balancer name.

fields.name: _rtTags
fields.documentation: A list of tag keys to remove.

operations.name: SetLoadBalancerListenerSSLCertificate
operations.documentation:
Sets the certificate that terminates the specified listener's SSL connections. The specified certificate replaces any prior certificate that was used on the same load balancer and port.

For more information on updating your SSL certificate, see Updating an SSL Certificate for a Load Balancer in the Elastic Load Balancing Developer Guide.

required.name: _slblsslcLoadBalancerName
required.documentation: The name of the load balancer.

required.name: _slblsslcLoadBalancerPort
required.documentation: The port that uses the specified SSL certificate.

required.name: _slblsslcSSLCertificateId
required.documentation: The Amazon Resource Number (ARN) of the SSL certificate chain to use. For more information on SSL certificates, see Managing Server Certificates in the AWS Identity and Access Management User Guide.

fields.name: _slblsslcLoadBalancerName
fields.documentation: The name of the load balancer.

fields.name: _slblsslcLoadBalancerPort
fields.documentation: The port that uses the specified SSL certificate.

fields.name: _slblsslcSSLCertificateId
fields.documentation: The Amazon Resource Number (ARN) of the SSL certificate chain to use. For more information on SSL certificates, see Managing Server Certificates in the AWS Identity and Access Management User Guide.

operations.name: SetLoadBalancerPoliciesForBackendServer
operations.documentation:
Replaces the current set of policies associated with a port on which the back-end server is listening with a new set of policies. After the policies have been created using CreateLoadBalancerPolicy, they can be applied here as a list. At this time, only the back-end server authentication policy type can be applied to the back-end ports; this policy type is composed of multiple public key policies.

The SetLoadBalancerPoliciesForBackendServer replaces the current set of policies associated with the specified instance port. Every time you use this action to enable the policies, use the PolicyNames parameter to list all the policies you want to enable.

You can use DescribeLoadBalancers or DescribeLoadBalancerPolicies action to verify that the policy has been associated with the back-end server.

required.name: _slbpfbsLoadBalancerName
required.documentation: The mnemonic name associated with the load balancer. This name must be unique within the set of your load balancers.

required.name: _slbpfbsInstancePort
required.documentation: The port number associated with the back-end server.

optional.name: _slbpfbsPolicyNames
optional.documentation: List of policy names to be set. If the list is empty, then all current polices are removed from the back-end server.

fields.name: _slbpfbsInstancePort
fields.documentation: The port number associated with the back-end server.

fields.name: _slbpfbsLoadBalancerName
fields.documentation: The mnemonic name associated with the load balancer. This name must be unique within the set of your load balancers.

fields.name: _slbpfbsPolicyNames
fields.documentation: List of policy names to be set. If the list is empty, then all current polices are removed from the back-end server.

operations.name: SetLoadBalancerPoliciesOfListener
operations.documentation: Associates, updates, or disables a policy with a listener on the load balancer. You can associate multiple policies with a listener.

required.name: _slbpolLoadBalancerName
required.documentation: The name of the load balancer.

required.name: _slbpolLoadBalancerPort
required.documentation: The external port of the load balancer to associate the policy.

optional.name: _slbpolPolicyNames
optional.documentation: List of policies to be associated with the listener. If the list is empty, the current policy is removed from the listener.

fields.name: _slbpolLoadBalancerName
fields.documentation: The name of the load balancer.

fields.name: _slbpolLoadBalancerPort
fields.documentation: The external port of the load balancer to associate the policy.

fields.name: _slbpolPolicyNames
fields.documentation: List of policies to be associated with the listener. If the list is empty, the current policy is removed from the listener.
